facts.1: The Milky Way is just one of billions of galaxies in the universe.
facts.2: The universe is approximately 13.8 billion years old.
facts.3: The speed of light is about 299,792 kilometers per second (186,282 miles per second).
facts.4: The closest star to Earth is the Sun, which is about 93 million miles away.
facts.5: The largest planet in our solar system is Jupiter.
facts.6: The smallest planet in our solar system is Mercury.
facts.7: Earth is the only known planet to support life.
facts.8: The International Space Station (ISS) travels at an average speed of 28,000 kilometers per hour (17,500 miles per hour).
facts.9: A day on Venus is longer than a year on Venus.
facts.10: Mars is often called the 'Red Planet' due to its reddish appearance.
facts.11: Neptune has the strongest winds in our solar system, reaching up to 1,200 miles per hour.
facts.12: Saturn's rings are made up of ice particles and rock debris.
facts.13: The Kuiper Belt is a region of the solar system beyond Neptune that contains many small, icy bodies.
facts.14: The Oort Cloud is a theoretical region that may contain comets and other icy bodies.
facts.15: Black holes are regions in space where gravity is so strong that nothing, not even light, can escape.
facts.16: A light-year is the distance light travels in one year, roughly 5.88 trillion miles (9.46 trillion kilometers).
facts.17: The largest volcano in the solar system is on Mars and is called Olympus Mons.
facts.18: The Great Red Spot on Jupiter is a massive storm that has been raging for at least 350 years.
facts.19: The Hubble Space Telescope has provided stunning images of distant galaxies and nebulae.
facts.20: Dark matter makes up about 27% of the universe.
facts.21: Dark energy, a mysterious force, makes up about 68% of the universe.
facts.22: The Andromeda Galaxy is on a collision course with our Milky Way Galaxy, but it won't happen for about 4 billion years.
facts.23: The first artificial satellite, Sputnik 1, was launched by the Soviet Union in 1957.
facts.24: The Moon is about 1/6th the size of Earth.
facts.25: The Moon has no atmosphere, which means there is no weather on the Moon.
facts.26: The Earth's atmosphere extends about 560 kilometers (348 miles) above the surface.
facts.27: The concept of a 'black hole' was first theorized by physicist John Archibald Wheeler in 1967.
facts.28: The largest asteroid in our solar system is Ceres.
facts.29: The first human to orbit the Earth was Yuri Gagarin in 1961.
facts.30: The Voyager 1 spacecraft has traveled farther from Earth than any other human-made object.
facts.31: A supernova is a massive explosion that occurs when a star reaches the end of its life cycle.
facts.32: The Crab Nebula is the remnant of a supernova observed by Chinese astronomers in the year 1054.
facts.33: The Northern Lights (Aurora Borealis) and Southern Lights (Aurora Australis) are caused by the interaction of solar particles with the Earth's atmosphere.
facts.34: The largest moon in our solar system is Ganymede, a moon of Jupiter.
facts.35: The concept of a wormhole, a hypothetical tunnel between two separate points in spacetime, was first introduced by physicist Albert Einstein and physicist Nathan Rosen.
facts.36: A neutron star is the collapsed core of a massive star that has undergone a supernova explosion.
facts.37: The Drake Equation is an attempt to estimate the number of active, communicative extraterrestrial civilizations in the Milky Way galaxy.
facts.38: The Sun contains more than 99.8% of the total mass of the entire solar system.
facts.39: The Sun's energy is produced through a process called nuclear fusion.
facts.40: The Hubble Constant is a measure of the rate at which the universe is expanding.
facts.41: A pulsar is a highly magnetized, rotating neutron star that emits beams of electromagnetic radiation.
facts.42: The concept of a 'white dwarf' was first proposed by Subrahmanyan Chandrasekhar.
facts.43: The Event Horizon Telescope captured the first-ever image of a black hole in 2019.
facts.44: The Great Attractor is a gravitational anomaly in intergalactic space that influences the motion of galaxies.
facts.45: The James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) is the planned successor to the Hubble Space Telescope.
facts.46: The concept of a 'multiverse' suggests the existence of multiple universes beyond our own.
facts.47: The concept of time dilation, as predicted by Einstein's theory of relativity, means that time can pass at different rates depending on gravity and velocity.
facts.48: A quasar is an extremely luminous and energetic active galactic nucleus.
facts.49: The cosmic microwave background (CMB) is the residual radiation from the Big Bang.
facts.50: The Pioneer and Voyager spacecraft carry messages intended for any extraterrestrial life that might encounter them.
facts.51: The Moon's gravitational pull causes Earth's tides.
facts.52: The Roche Limit is the minimum distance at which a celestial body, held together only by gravity, will disintegrate due to tidal forces exceeding the body's gravitational self-attraction.
facts.53: The concept of a Dyson Sphere involves enclosing a star to capture its energy for a civilization's use.
facts.54: The term 'asteroid belt' refers to the region between the orbits of Mars and Jupiter where many asteroids are found.
facts.55: The space probe New Horizons provided the first close-up images of Pluto in 2015.
facts.56: The International Astronomical Union (IAU) is the organization responsible for classifying celestial bodies and defining the criteria for what constitutes a planet.
facts.57: The concept of 'space junk' refers to defunct human-made objects, fragments, and debris in orbit around Earth.
facts.58: The Chicxulub crater in Mexico is believed to be the impact site of the asteroid or comet that led to the extinction of the dinosaurs.
facts.59: The term 'Big Bang' was coined by astronomer Fred Hoyle, who was a proponent of the steady-state theory.
facts.60: The Fermi Paradox highlights the apparent contradiction between the high probability of extraterrestrial civilizations and the lack of evidence for or contact with such civilizations.
facts.61: The Juno spacecraft is studying Jupiter's composition, gravity field, magnetic field, and polar magnetosphere.
facts.62: The concept of 'space tourism' involves private individuals traveling to space for recreational purposes.
facts.63: The Tunguska event in 1908 was a mysterious explosion believed to have been caused by the airburst of a large meteoroid or comet.
facts.64: The concept of the 'habitable zone' or 'Goldilocks zone' refers to the range of distances from a star where conditions may be suitable for life.
facts.65: The space shuttle Challenger disaster occurred in 1986 when the shuttle broke apart 73 seconds into its flight, leading to the deaths of seven crew members.
facts.66: The Great Filter is a hypothetical explanation for the apparent rarity of extraterrestrial civilizations.
facts.67: The Oumuamua object, which passed through our solar system in 2017, is considered the first interstellar object detected passing through our solar system.
facts.68: The concept of a 'space elevator' involves a structure extending from the Earth's surface into space, providing a more cost-effective means of transporting goods and people into space.
facts.69: The Lagrange points are positions in space where the gravitational forces of two large bodies combine to create enhanced regions of attraction and repulsion.
facts.70: The concept of a 'warp drive' is a speculative idea for faster-than-light travel, often associated with science fiction.
facts.71: The space probe Cassini studied Saturn and its moons, providing valuable data about the planet's atmosphere and rings.
facts.72: The concept of 'terraforming' involves the deliberate modification of a planet's atmosphere, temperature, and ecology to make it habitable for humans.
facts.73: The space agency ESA (European Space Agency) collaborates with NASA on various space missions.
facts.74: The Huygens probe, part of the Cassini-Huygens mission, successfully landed on Saturn's moon Titan in 2005.
facts.75: The concept of a 'megabyte' was popularized by astrophysicist Carl Sagan to describe the vast amount of information that could be transmitted in a short time using radio signals.
facts.76: The concept of 'space colonization' involves the establishment of human habitats beyond Earth, such as on Mars or in orbiting space stations.
facts.77: The ALMA (Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array) observatory is located in the Atacama Desert in Chile and studies the universe in millimeter and submillimeter wavelengths.
facts.78: The space probe Rosetta successfully deployed the Philae lander to study the comet 67P/Churyumovâ€“Gerasimenko in 2014.
facts.79: The concept of a 'space telescope' refers to telescopes placed in outer space to observe astronomical objects without the distortion caused by Earth's atmosphere.
facts.80: The concept of a 'space suit' is essential for astronauts to survive and work in the vacuum of space.
facts.81: The space agency JAXA (Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency) is known for its missions like Hayabusa, which successfully returned samples from an asteroid.
facts.82: The concept of 'astronaut ice cream' is a freeze-dried treat that became popularized despite not being a standard space food.
facts.83: The space probe Voyager 1 carries a Golden Record containing sounds and images of Earth, intended to be a message to any extraterrestrial intelligence that might find it.
facts.84: The concept of a 'rogue planet' refers to a planet that does not orbit a star and instead floats freely through space.
facts.85: The space shuttle Atlantis completed the final space shuttle mission (STS-135) in 2011.
facts.86: The concept of 'astrobiology' involves the study of the potential for life beyond Earth and the conditions necessary for life to exist.
facts.87: The concept of 'rocket equation' describes the physics of rocket propulsion and the relationship between velocity, mass, and fuel.
facts.88: The space probe New Horizons conducted a historic flyby of Pluto and its moons in 2015, providing valuable data about these distant bodies.
facts.89: The concept of 'space junk tracking' involves monitoring and cataloging the thousands of pieces of debris in Earth's orbit to avoid collisions with active satellites and spacecraft.
facts.90: The space telescope Kepler discovered thousands of exoplanets, including many in the habitable zone of their stars.
facts.91: The concept of 'astrochemistry' involves the study of the chemical composition of celestial objects and the processes that occur in space.
facts.92: The space probe InSight landed on Mars in 2018, studying the planet's interior and seismic activity.
facts.93: The concept of 'space mining' involves extracting valuable resources, such as minerals and metals, from celestial bodies like asteroids or the Moon.
facts.94: The space agency ISRO (Indian Space Research Organisation) successfully launched the Mars Orbiter Mission (Mangalyaan) in 2013.
facts.95: The concept of 'gravitational lensing' occurs when the gravitational field of a massive object bends and focuses light from a more distant object.
facts.96: You could survive for a couple of minutes in a leaky spacesuit.
facts.97: The concept of 'space weather' involves the environmental conditions in space as influenced by the Sun and the solar wind.
facts.98: The space probe Dawn studied the dwarf planet Ceres, providing insights into its composition and history.
facts.99: The concept of 'space law' involves the legal framework governing activities in outer space, including international agreements and treaties.
facts.100: The space telescope Spitzer, part of NASA's Great Observatories program, studied the universe in infrared wavelengths, providing unique insights into celestial objects and phenomena.
facts.101: The Sombrero Galaxy (M104) gets its name from its resemblance to a wide-brimmed Mexican hat.
facts.102: Astronauts experience 'space fog' as a result of dust particles in microgravity, causing a hazy appearance.
facts.103: The concept of a 'Blue Moon' refers to the second full moon in a calendar month.
facts.104: The Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope studies gamma-ray bursts, the most energetic events in the universe.
facts.105: The asteroid belt is not as densely packed with asteroids as often portrayed in science fiction.
facts.106: The space probe Hayabusa2 successfully collected samples from the asteroid Ryugu and returned to Earth in 2020.
facts.107: The Great Dark Spot observed on Neptune by the Voyager 2 spacecraft disappeared in subsequent Hubble Space Telescope images.
facts.108: The concept of 'panspermia' suggests that life on Earth may have originated from microorganisms or chemical precursors of life transported through space.
facts.109: The space probe Magellan mapped the surface of Venus using radar, revealing a volcanic and mountainous terrain.
facts.110: Astronomer Edwin Hubble discovered that the universe is expanding, leading to the formulation of Hubble's Law.
facts.111: The space probe Galileo discovered evidence of a subsurface ocean on Jupiter's moon Europa.
facts.112: The concept of 'space elevators' is explored as a potential future technology for transporting payloads from Earth to space using a cable anchored to the planet's surface.
facts.113: The Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN recreates conditions similar to the early universe to study particle physics.
facts.114: The concept of 'dark flow' suggests that galaxy clusters are moving in a consistent direction, possibly influenced by matter outside the observable universe.
facts.115: The space probe Parker Solar Probe is designed to study the outer corona of the Sun and understand solar wind acceleration.
facts.116: The Zodiacal Light is a faint, triangular glow caused by sunlight scattering off interplanetary dust in the plane of the solar system.
facts.117: The space probe OSIRIS-REx successfully collected samples from the asteroid Bennu and is scheduled to return to Earth in 2023.
facts.118: The concept of 'gravitational waves' was confirmed by the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (LIGO) in 2015.
facts.119: The space probe Voyager 2 is the only spacecraft to have visited Uranus and Neptune, providing valuable data about these ice giants.
facts.120: The concept of 'cosmic inflation' suggests that the universe experienced an exponential expansion in the first moments after the Big Bang.
facts.121: The space telescope Chandra observes X-rays from high-energy regions of the universe, such as supernova remnants and black hole accretion disks.
facts.122: The concept of a 'tesseract' is a four-dimensional hypercube, often used in science fiction as a representation of higher-dimensional space.
facts.123: The space probe Akatsuki is studying Venus's atmosphere and weather patterns, including its mysterious super-rotation.
facts.124: The concept of 'quantum entanglement' involves particles becoming correlated in ways that defy classical physics, even when separated by large distances.
facts.125: The space telescope Gaia is mapping the positions and motions of over one billion stars in the Milky Way to create a 3D stellar census.
facts.126: The concept of 'cosmic strings' involves theoretical linear objects that may have formed during the early universe's phase transitions.
facts.127: The space probe MAVEN is studying the Martian atmosphere to understand the processes that led to the loss of much of its water.
facts.128: The concept of 'exomoons' refers to moons orbiting planets outside our solar system.
facts.129: The space telescope TESS (Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite) is dedicated to finding planets orbiting the brightest stars in Earth's vicinity.
facts.130: The concept of 'quantum tunneling' allows particles to pass through barriers that classical physics would consider impenetrable.
facts.131: The space probe BepiColombo, a joint mission of ESA and JAXA, is en route to Mercury to study its composition and magnetic field.
facts.132: The concept of 'stellar nurseries' refers to regions in space where new stars are born from the gravitational collapse of gas and dust.
facts.133: The space telescope WFIRST (Wide Field Infrared Survey Telescope) is planned to study dark energy, exoplanets, and infrared astrophysics.
facts.134: The concept of 'quantum superposition' allows particles to exist in multiple states simultaneously until observed.
facts.135: The space probe InSight placed a seismometer on Mars to study its internal structure and seismic activity.
facts.136: The concept of 'quantum computing' explores the use of quantum-mechanical phenomena to perform computation.
facts.137: The space telescope ATHENA (Advanced Telescope for High Energy Astrophysics) is planned to study hot gas in galaxy clusters and other high-energy phenomena.
facts.138: The concept of 'string theory' proposes that fundamental particles are not point-like but instead tiny, vibrating strings.
facts.139: The space probe Hayabusa returned samples from the asteroid Itokawa, providing insights into the early solar system.
facts.140: The concept of 'quantum entanglement' was famously described by Albert Einstein as 'spooky action at a distance.'
facts.141: The space telescope Euclid is designed to investigate dark energy and dark matter by surveying galaxies and measuring their shapes and redshifts.
facts.142: The concept of 'quantum teleportation' involves transferring the quantum state of one particle to another without physical transfer of the particle itself.
facts.143: The space probe OSIRIS-REx is named after the Egyptian god Osiris and stands for Origins, Spectral Interpretation, Resource Identification, and Security-Regolith Explorer.
facts.144: The concept of 'quantum cryptography' uses principles of quantum mechanics to secure communication.
facts.145: The space telescope JWST (James Webb Space Telescope) is planned to be the most powerful space telescope, studying the universe in infrared wavelengths.
facts.146: The concept of 'quantum superposition' is exemplified by SchrÃ¶dinger's famous thought experiment involving a cat that is both alive and dead until observed.
facts.147: The space probe Juno is studying Jupiter's magnetic field, gravity field, and polar magnetosphere.
facts.148: Space does not begin at a specific altitude above the Earth, but the KÃ¡rmÃ¡n line at 100 km is a commonly used definition.
facts.149: The International Space Station is the largest ever crewed object in space.
facts.150: Space is a hard vacuum, meaning it is a void containing very little matter.
facts.151: The space between galaxies is not completely empty but has an average of one atom per cubic meter.
facts.152: The concept of 'quantum gravity' aims to unify the principles of quantum mechanics and general relativity to describe gravity at the quantum level.
facts.153: The space telescope PLATO (PLAnetary Transits and Oscillations of stars) is designed to find and study exoplanets by detecting their transits and oscillations.
facts.154: The concept of 'quantum field theory' provides a framework for combining quantum mechanics and special relativity to describe particle physics.
facts.155: The space probe Rosalind Franklin (formerly ExoMars Rover) is planned to search for signs of past or present life on Mars.
facts.156: The concept of 'quantum foam' refers to the fluctuating structure of spacetime at extremely small scales according to quantum mechanics.
facts.157: The space telescope LISA (Laser Interferometer Space Antenna) is planned to detect and observe gravitational waves from massive cosmic objects.
facts.158: The concept of 'quantum decoherence' explains the transition from quantum superposition to classical probability in a measurable system.
facts.159: The space probe Lucy is named after the fossilized hominid skeleton 'Lucy,' symbolizing the mission's exploration of ancient building blocks of planets.
facts.160: The concept of 'quantum biology' explores the role of quantum phenomena in biological processes, such as photosynthesis.
facts.161: The space telescope Roman (formerly WFIRST) is planned to search for dark matter, dark energy, and study exoplanets through gravitational microlensing.
facts.162: The concept of 'quantum entanglement' is exploited in quantum communication protocols, such as quantum key distribution for secure communication.
facts.163: The space probe Psyche is planned to explore the metallic asteroid 16 Psyche, believed to be the exposed nickel-iron core of a protoplanet.
facts.164: The concept of 'quantum tunneling' is responsible for nuclear fusion processes in stars, allowing them to produce energy.
facts.165: The space telescope Athena (Advanced Telescope for High ENergy Astrophysics) is designed to study the hot and energetic universe.
facts.166: The concept of 'quantum computing' holds the potential to solve certain problems much faster than classical computers through parallel processing.
facts.167: The space probe VERITAS (Venus Emissivity, Radio Science, InSAR, Topography, and Spectroscopy) is planned to map Venus's surface and subsurface.
facts.168: The concept of 'quantum superposition' is essential for quantum algorithms, such as Shor's algorithm for factoring large numbers.
facts.169: The space telescope SPHEREx (Spectro-Photometer for the History of the Universe, Epoch of Reionization, and Ices Explorer) is planned to study the early universe.
facts.170: The concept of 'quantum cryptography' enables the secure exchange of cryptographic keys using quantum properties.
facts.171: The space probe Dragonfly is planned to explore Saturn's moon Titan, studying prebiotic chemistry and extraterrestrial habitability.
facts.172: The concept of 'quantum teleportation' involves transferring the quantum state of one particle to another over a distance without direct transfer of matter.
facts.173: The space telescope WFIRST (Wide Field Infrared Survey Telescope) is planned to investigate the nature of dark energy and study exoplanets.
facts.174: The concept of 'quantum superposition' is demonstrated in quantum interference experiments, such as the double-slit experiment.
facts.175: The space probe IXPE (Imaging X-ray Polarimetry Explorer) is designed to measure the polarization of cosmic X-rays to study exotic objects in the universe.
facts.176: The concept of 'quantum computing' explores the potential to solve complex problems, such as optimization and simulation, more efficiently than classical computers.
facts.177: The space telescope ATHENA (Advanced Telescope for High Energy Astrophysics) is planned to study the hot gas in galaxy clusters and other high-energy phenomena.
facts.178: The concept of 'string theory' suggests that fundamental particles are not point-like but instead tiny, vibrating strings.
facts.179: The space probe Hayabusa returned samples from the asteroid Itokawa, providing insights into the early solar system.
facts.180: The concept of 'quantum entanglement' was famously described by Albert Einstein as 'spooky action at a distance.'
facts.181: The space telescope Euclid is designed to investigate dark energy and dark matter by surveying galaxies and measuring their shapes and redshifts.
facts.182: The concept of 'quantum teleportation' involves transferring the quantum state of one particle to another without physical transfer of the particle itself.
facts.183: The space probe OSIRIS-REx is named after the Egyptian god Osiris and stands for Origins, Spectral Interpretation, Resource Identification, and Security-Regolith Explorer.
facts.184: The concept of 'quantum cryptography' uses principles of quantum mechanics to secure communication.
facts.185: The space telescope JWST (James Webb Space Telescope) is planned to be the most powerful space telescope, studying the universe in infrared wavelengths.
facts.186: The concept of 'quantum superposition' is exemplified by SchrÃ¶dinger's famous thought experiment involving a cat that is both alive and dead until observed.
facts.187: On Mercury a day is twice as long as a year.
facts.188: The universe is observed to be 13.8 billion years old and has been expanding since its formation in the Big Bang.
facts.189: In the observable universe there are an estimated 2 trillion (2,000,000,000,000) galaxies.
facts.190: The temperature in the void of space is about âˆ’270.45 Â°C.
facts.191: The space probe Lucy is on a mission to study Jupiter's Trojan asteroids, ancient remnants from the early solar system.
facts.192: The concept of 'quantum gravity' aims to unify the principles of quantum mechanics and general relativity to describe gravity at the quantum level.
facts.193: The space telescope PLATO (PLAnetary Transits and Oscillations of stars) is designed to find and study exoplanets by detecting their transits and oscillations.
facts.194: The concept of 'quantum field theory' provides a framework for combining quantum mechanics and special relativity to describe particle physics.
facts.195: The space probe Rosalind Franklin (formerly ExoMars Rover) is planned to search for signs of past or present life on Mars.
facts.196: The concept of 'quantum foam' refers to the fluctuating structure of spacetime at extremely small scales according to quantum mechanics.
facts.197: The space telescope LISA (Laser Interferometer Space Antenna) is planned to detect and observe gravitational waves from massive cosmic objects.
facts.198: The concept of 'quantum decoherence' explains the transition from quantum superposition to classical probability in a measurable system.
facts.199: The space probe Lucy is named after the fossilized hominid skeleton 'Lucy,' symbolizing the mission's exploration of ancient building blocks of planets.
